docs.lead_paragraph: With passage of a $792 billion tax cut secured, Congress left for its August recess early today and set the stage for a high-stakes autumn confrontation with President Clinton over the nation's fiscal priorities in the new era of projected Federal surpluses. The battle over how to divide the expected $3 trillion windfall among tax cuts, Federal programs and debt reduction through the next decade is the most far reaching of many ideologically charged policy disputes expected to be joined in the fall. Others include debates over gun control, regulation of managed care and an overhaul of the campaign finance laws.

headline.main: With Fiscal Battle Plans Drawn, Lawmakers Begin Recess

docs.abstract: Congress leaves for its August recess, setting stage for high-stakes fall confrontation with Pres Clinton over expected Federal budget surplus, other ideologically charged issues; Clinton again vows to veto Republicans' tax cut; House Speaker Dennis Hastert and other Republican leaders agree to let managed-care bill planned by Reps Tom Coburn and John Shadegg move forward in fall; table of issues pending before Congress; photo (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Prudential Healthcare for about $1 billion, after wrestling with outside objections to the acquisition for more than half a year. The purchase, Aetna's third of a managed health care company since 1996, will add about 5.5 million health insurance customers. The transaction also lets Prudential Healthcare's parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, shed a money-losing business as it converts to a stock company from one owned by policyholders.

headline.main: ACQUISITION OF PRUDENTIAL HEALTHCARE IS COMPLETED

docs.snippet: Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Prudential Healthcare for about $1 billion, after wrestling with outside objections to the acquisition for more than half a year. The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some 90 percent of the hired care that old people get, either in their own homes or in nursing homes, is given by nurses' aides. The aides do the basic, intimate things, the waking, toileting, bathing, dressing, feeding and bedding down for the night. It is their eyes, their voices, their manner and touch that form the texture of daily life for millions of dependent old people -- a population that suffers not only from collapsing mental and physical states, but also from simple, profound feelings of loneliness and depression. The work is not easy, or always safe. Nurses' aides injure themselves or fall ill at twice the average of workers in private industry. Many get no health insurance. Not surprisingly, in this high-employment economy, such jobs have gotten hard to fill. Ombudsmen in 41 states have reported that nursing homes cannot recruit and retain the aides they need.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Federal and state governments to weigh raising standards and wages of nurses aides who care for aged in nursing homes and in private homes

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of dissident Republicans reached agreement with House Democrats today on a comprehensive bill to regulate the managed health care industry and predicted they would have enough support to force the Republican leadership to bring their measure to a vote. The proposal, which would cover all 161 million Americans with private health insurance and give them expanded rights to sue insurance companies, was hastily made public by a bipartisan group of House members late this afternoon, as they scrambled to introduce it and get the edge on the potent health issue before Congress left for its August recess.

headline.main: Some in G.O.P. Join Democrats On H.M.O. Bill

docs.abstract: Dissident Republican group reaches agreement with House Democrats on comprehensive bill to regulate managed health care industry and predicts they will have enough support to force Republican leadership to bring their measure to vote; proposal would cover all 161 million Americans with private health insurance and give them expanded rights to sue insurance companies; Pres Clinton, who has vowed to veto Senate's more limited approach to managed care legislation, quickly endorses bipartisan House measure and calls on Speaker J Dennis Hastert to schedule vote as soon as Congress returns in September; virtually all House Democrats are expected to coalesce around bill; several health industry groups immediately denounce bill, claiming it will lead to rising costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN 18-year-old Eamon Walsh and two of his high school friends get together, they chat about summer concerts, the heat and -- more often than not -- their marketing plan. Instead of rising at noon and heading to the pool, Mr. Walsh backs his car out of the driveway before 7 A.M., picks up his friends -- Tamara Metz, 18, and Thomas Purtell, 17 -- and heads to work at Evolve, an Internet company in Vienna, Va.

headline.main: What I Did On My Summer Vacation; Some Teen-Agers Parlayed Computer Skills Into Jobs With Signing Bonuses, Travel and Executive Perks

docs.abstract: Computer-savvy students in high school or their first few years of college are landing summer jobs that look like professional, full-time employment; some are making enough money to cover most of their tuition, while others are receiving signing bonuses simply for accepting summer employment; phenomenon has emerged over last few years, as Internet start-up companies have proliferated and established software and hardware companies have grown; finding enough people to do technical work has become primary concern, and companies fear they are missing out on talent if they focus only on college juniors and seniors; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Green, one of the best tight ends of the decade and one of the new Jets who upgraded the team over the off season, missed today's two-a-day practice because of a chronic left knee problem. Both Bill Parcells and Green expressed concern with the knee, although the coach seemed surprised by the seriousness of the problem, which he declined to call an injury. Asked what the exact name of the trouble is, the 32-year-old Green had a ready answer: ''Just one of those knees that's been around a long time.''

headline.main: Green's Ailing Knee Adds to Parcells's Worries

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Uwe E. Reinhardt (letter, Aug. 3) suggests that an alternative to maintaining the health care system run by the Department of Veterans Affairs would be to give American veterans private health insurance. Yet there is much the V.A. system does that would be difficult to replicate in the marketplace.

headline.main: Veterans' Health System Can't Be Replaced

docs.lead_paragraph: American lawyers may be at the peak of their power. Achieving victories in court that could not be won in Congress, they are playing ever more pivotal roles in public issues from sex discrimination and civil rights to tobacco and the current battles over guns and Microsoft. The size and wealth of the profession is greater than it has ever been.

headline.main: Lawyers Contend With State and Federal Efforts to Restrict Their Rising Power

docs.abstract: American lawyers face new restrictions owing to increasing criticisms of garguantuan legal fees and excessive litigation; have been barred entirely from filing certain types of suits by state Legislatures and courts, which have also tried to limit type of advice they can give; some complain that new business and professional trends are further limiting their autonomy and that their decisions are increasingly being second-guessed by insurance companies and others reviewing their actions; acknowledge new limits and suits are response to legitimate public concerns, but warn that as their influence is restricted, Americans will lose ability to turn to legal system for help; American Bar Assn president, Philip S Anderson, comments; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Representative Tom A. Coburn (''Patients' Rights, Done Wrong,'' Op-Ed, July 30) overlooks the first and foremost right of patients: the right of accessible, affordable health care. Tens of millions of uninsured patients in this country lack this right.
